items.title: Three teir TLD incorrectly sliced
items.body:
**Expected result:**
```
>>> tldextract.extract("prod.environment.nsw.gov.au")
ExtractResult(subdomain='prod', domain='environment', suffix='nsw.gov.au')
```
**Actual result:**
```
>>> tldextract.extract("prod.environment.nsw.gov.au")
ExtractResult(subdomain='prod.environment', domain='nsw', suffix='gov.au')
```
It may be getting confused because `.gov.au` is a TLD, but so is `.nsw.gov.au`
The solution may be to match the longest possible TLD first and keep dropping levels until successful.

items.title: [INFO] TypeError: super() takes at least 1 argument (0 given)
items.body:
Just because some people will obviously get this stracktrace I'll post this info. A few hours ago an update of requests-file from 1.4.3 to 1.5.0 broke tldextract on python:2.7. The fix is to harcode request-file==1.4.3 (or update to python 3 obviously).

Python 3 works:
```
# docker run --rm -ti python:3 bash -c "pip --quiet install tldextract && pip freeze && python -c \"import tldextract;print(tldextra
ct.extract('www.google.com'))\""
certifi==2020.4.5.1
chardet==3.0.4
idna==2.9
requests==2.23.0
requests-file==1.5.0
six==1.14.0
tldextract==2.2.2
urllib3==1.25.9
ExtractResult(subdomain='www', domain='google', suffix='com')
```

Python 2.7 with requests-file==1.5.0 doesn't:
```
# docker run --rm -ti python:2.7 bash -c "pip --quiet install tldextract && pip freeze && python -c \"import tldextract;print(tldext
ract.extract('www.google.com'))\""
on of pip will drop support for Python 2.7.
certifi==2020.4.5.1
chardet==3.0.4
idna==2.9
requests==2.23.0
requests-file==1.5.0
six==1.14.0
tldextract==2.2.2
urllib3==1.25.9
virtualenv==16.6.0
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<string>", line 1, in <module> 
  File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/tldextract/tldextract.py", line 353, in extract
    return TLD_EXTRACTOR(url)
  File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/tldextract/tldextract.py", line 233, in __call__
    suffix_index = self._get_tld_extractor().suffix_index(translations)
  File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/tldextract/tldextract.py", line 276, in _get_tld_extractor
    self.cache_fetch_timeout
  File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/tldextract/remote.py", line 33, in find_first_response
    session.mount('file://', FileAdapter())
  File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/requests_file.py", line 14, in __init__
    super().__init__()
TypeError: super() takes at least 1 argument (0 given)
```

python 2.7 with requests-file==1.4.3 does:
```
# docker run --rm -ti python:2.7 bash -c "pip --quiet install tldextract requests-file==1.4.3 && pip freeze && python -c \"import tldextract;print(tldextract.extract('www.google.com'))\""

six==1.14.0
tldextract==2.2.2
urllib3==1.25.9
virtualenv==16.6.0
ExtractResult(subdomain='www', domain='google', suffix='com')
```

items.title: IndexError with malformed punycode text
items.body:
In Python 3.6, running
```python3
import tldextract
tldextract.extract("xn--w&")
```

will cause an IndexError.

```
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
  File "/censored-path/lib/python3.6/site-packages/tldextract/tldextract.py", line 353, in extract
    return TLD_EXTRACTOR(url)
  File "/censored-path/lib/python3.6/site-packages/tldextract/tldextract.py", line 232, in __call__
    translations = [_decode_punycode(label) for label in labels]
  File "/censored-path/lib/python3.6/site-packages/tldextract/tldextract.py", line 232, in <listcomp>
    translations = [_decode_punycode(label) for label in labels]
  File "/censored-path/lib/python3.6/site-packages/tldextract/tldextract.py", line 405, in _decode_punycode
    return idna.decode(label.encode('ascii')).lower()
  File "/censored-path/lib/python3.6/site-packages/idna/core.py", line 392, in decode
    s = ulabel(label)
  File "/censored-path/lib/python3.6/site-packages/idna/core.py", line 310, in ulabel
    label = label.decode('punycode')
IndexError: decoding with 'punycode' codec failed (IndexError: string index out of range)
```

This is due to a bug with Python's punycode decoding, which you can reproduce by running
```python3
"xn--w&".encode("ascii").decode("punycode")
```

This was reported here: https://bugs.python.org/msg295270
and patched here: https://github.com/python/cpython/pull/1986
but the fix was only backported to Python 3.7 and 3.8.

Applying the patch from the Python repository fixes this issue.

Could IndexError also be caught in `tldextract.py:_decode_punycode()` as a workaround?

items.title: tldextract.update() strange behaviour
items.body:
I just try to make a script to find out whether a domain make use of ccTLD, and differentiate between public or private domains.  

So I initiate 2 explicit tldextract class that deal with this with explicit include_psl_private_domains switch. However, I notice the class behave differently if you "trigger" the extract ASAP than later on. 


Code #1 show include_psl_private_domains=True works if I "test" the class function immediately. 
```
# Trigger the extract immeidately 
import tldextract
url = "www.blogspot.co.za"
expub = tldextract.TLDExtract(include_psl_private_domains=False)
expub.update()
expub(url)
# result : ExtractResult(subdomain='www', domain='blogspot', suffix='co.za')

expri = tldextract.TLDExtract(include_psl_private_domains=True)
expri.update()
expri(url)
# result : ExtractResult(subdomain='', domain='www', suffix='blogspot.co.za')

url2 = "another.blogspot.co.uk"
expub(url2)
# result : ExtractResult(subdomain='another', domain='blogspot', suffix='co.uk')
expri(url2)
# result : ExtractResult(subdomain='', domain='another', suffix='blogspot.co.uk')
```

In following code, include_psl_private_domains=True doesn't work as intended 
```
import tldextract
url = "www.blogspot.co.za"
expub = tldextract.TLDExtract(include_psl_private_domains=False)
expub.update()
expri = tldextract.TLDExtract(include_psl_private_domains=True)
expri.update()

expub(url)
# result : ExtractResult(subdomain='www', domain='blogspot', suffix='co.za')
expri(url) 
# result : ExtractResult(subdomain='www', domain='blogspot', suffix='co.za')

# Try another domain 
url2 = "another.blogspot.co.uk"
expub(url2)
# result : ExtractResult(subdomain='another', domain='blogspot', suffix='co.uk')
expri(url2) 
# result : ExtractResult(subdomain='another', domain='blogspot', suffix='co.uk')
```

items.title: Potential dependency conflicts between tldextract and idna
items.body:
Hi, as shown in the following full dependency graph of  **_tldextract_**, **_tldextract_** requires **_idna *_** ， while the installed version of **_requests_**(2.22.0) requires _**idna >=2.5,<2.9**_.

According to Pip's _“first found wins”_ installation strategy, _**idna 2.8**_ is the actually installed version.  

Although the first found package version _**idna 2.8**_ just satisfies the later dependency constraint （_**idna >=2.5,<2.9**_), it will lead to a build failure once developers release a newer version of idna.

### Dependency tree--------
```

tldextract - 2.2.2
| +- idna(install version:2.8 version range:*)
| +- requests(install version:2.22.0 version range:>=2.1.0)
| | +- certifi(install version:2019.9.11 version range:>=2017.4.17)
| | +- chardet(install version:3.0.4 version range:<3.1.0,>=3.0.2)
| | +- idna(install version:2.8 version range:>=2.5,<2.9)
| | +- urllib3(install version:1.25.7 version range:<1.26,>=1.21.1)
| +- requests-file(install version:1.4.3 version range:>=1.4)
| | +- requests(install version:2.22.0 version range:>=1.0.0)
| | | +- certifi(install version:2019.9.11 version range:>=2017.4.17)
| | | +- chardet(install version:3.0.4 version range:<3.1.0,>=3.0.2)
| | | +- idna(install version:2.8 version range:>=2.5,<2.9)
| | | +- urllib3(install version:1.25.7 version range:<1.26,>=1.21.1)
| | +- six(install version:1.13.0 version range:*)
| +- setuptools(install version:42.0.1 version range:*) 
```

Thanks for your attention.
Best,
Neolith

items.body:
when passing extra_suffixes to tldextract they do not seem to be added to `self.tlds`

to reproduce
`from tldextract import TLDExtract
domain = "www.xyz.eu.com"
extractor = TLDExtract(fallback_to_snapshot=True, extra_suffixes='eu.com')
assert(extractor.tlds.__contains__("eu.com"))
print(extractor(domain).suffix)`

items.title: Unnecessarily costly import
items.body: The main `__init__.py` import the version from the `cli` module. The `cli` module has *expensive* import-time side effects, which leak into any import. The result is immediately visible on the following flame-graph gathered with py-spy: This is a whopping 1.8s added to startup time! This should be easy to fix by moving the version field to a separate file which is imported by both the `cli` and the main API, allowing the main API to stay clear of the `cli` module.

items.title: Wrong extraction for some valid domains
items.body:
The following domains all work, yet `www` is recognized as domain instead of subdomain, and the actual domain is wrongly prepended to the suffix. Although it is clear that `www` is not a domain, but rather a special subdomain, this doesn't yet negatively impact the `registered_domain` and `fqdn` methods.
```
Python 3.6.8 (default, Jan 19 2019, 21:26:02)
[GCC 4.2.1 Compatible Apple LLVM 10.0.0 (clang-1000.10.44.4)] on darwin
Type "help", "copyright", "credits" or "license" for more information.
>>> import tldextract

>>> tldextract.__version__
'2.2.1'

>>> tldextract.extract('www.experts-comptables.fr')
ExtractResult(subdomain='', domain='www', suffix='experts-comptables.fr')

>>> tldextract.extract('www.gob.mx')
ExtractResult(subdomain='', domain='www', suffix='gob.mx')

>>> tldextract.extract('www.ma.gov.br')
ExtractResult(subdomain='', domain='www', suffix='ma.gov.br')

>>> tldextract.extract('www.wroclaw.pl')
ExtractResult(subdomain='', domain='www', suffix='wroclaw.pl')
```
But when passing the same domains without `www`, the whole input ends up in the suffix, and both `registered_domain` and `fqdn` functions wrongly return an empty string.

I've read up on #138 and some more related issues in this repo, but I'm pretty sure this can't be intended behaviour?

items.title: The .tld_set TLDs are different from the public_suffix_list.dat
items.body:
As I explained in previous issues, for some reasons I can not perform the `tldextract --update `command. Therefore, as stated in the home page, I use the alternative method, and I delete the cache before I run the program that calls the tldextract so I get an updated list.

However, I compared the tldextract TLDs that are in the cache with the available domains in the [public-suffix list](https://github.com/publicsuffix/list/blob/master/public_suffix_list.dat). The steps are as follows:

1) copy/pase the [public-suffix list](https://github.com/publicsuffix/list/blob/master/public_suffix_list.dat) in a file and clean empty lines or comments using this command:
`grep -v -E '^($|//)'`
 
2) Read the tldextract TLDs from the` .tld_set` file using python, then write them to a new file with each TLD in a line

3) using regex, clean the files to only contain TLDs with english letters: `[A-Za-z_0-9.-]+`

items.title: Potential dependency conflicts between tldextract and idna
items.body:
Hi, as shown in the following full dependency graph of  **_tldextract_**, **_tldextract_** requires _**idna**_ (the latest version)， while the installed version of **_requests_**(2.22.0) requires _**idna>=2.5,<2.9**_.

According to Pip's “first found wins” installation strategy, _**idna 2.8**_ is the actually installed version.  

Although the first found package version _**idna 2.8**_ just satisfies the later dependency constraint (_**idna>=2.5,<2.9**_), it will lead to a build failure once developers release a newer version of **_idna_**.

### Dependency tree--------
```
+-tldextract(version range:)
| +-setuptools(version range:)
| +-idna(version range:)
| +-requests(version range:>=2.1.0)
| | +-chardet(version range:>=3.0.2,<3.1.0)
| | +-idna(version range:>=2.5,<2.9)
| | +-urllib3(version range:>=1.21.1,<1.26)
| | +-certifi(version range:>=2017.4.17)
| +-requests-file(version range:>=1.4)
```

Thanks for your attention.
Best,
Neolith

`tldextract` seems to be giving incorrect results for `de.com` domains. Its results are inconsistant with the [tld](https://pypi.python.org/pypi/tld) python library, and [tldjs](https://github.com/oncletom/tld.js) in Javascript.

Likewise tldjs gets the same result:

items.title: IDNA URLs with uppercase XN-- not split correctly

labels.name: low priority: caller can pre/post-process
labels.description: lenient by design, it is up to you to clean your inputs (see README)

items.body:
AFAICT from [RFC 3490](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc3490) the 'xn--' prefix check (apparently added in https://github.com/john-kurkowski/tldextract/issues/48) should be case insensitive:

> The ACE prefix for IDNA is "xn--" or any capitalization thereof.

Current behavior:

```
>>> import tldextract
>>> tldextract.extract('test.xn--p1ai')
ExtractResult(subdomain='', domain='test', suffix='xn--p1ai')
>>> tldextract.extract('test.Xn--p1ai')
ExtractResult(subdomain='test', domain='Xn--p1ai', suffix='')
>>> tldextract.extract('test.XN--p1ai')
ExtractResult(subdomain='test', domain='XN--p1ai', suffix='')
>>> tldextract.extract('test.xN--p1ai')
ExtractResult(subdomain='test', domain='xN--p1ai', suffix='')
```

items.title: proposal: ipv4 property
items.body:
I wanted to propose a property to support potential IPv4 addresses.

This is definitely offtopic as an IPv4 isn't a TLD - however the input to this library can often be a URL and it is often used as part of URL/HOST validation.  Detecting this within the package makes it a bit easier for developers to support handling situations where a the 'domain' is invalid, however it is a valid resource.

A possible implementation is below -- in the absence of a suffix or subdomain, the domain is checked to match 4 groups of integers 0-255.  

    @property
    def ipv4(self):
        """
        Returns the ipv4 if that is what the presented domain/url is

        >>> extract('http://127.0.0.1/path/to/file').ipv4
        '127.0.0.1'
        >>> extract('http://127.0.0.1.1/path/to/file').ipv4
        ''
        >>> extract('http://256.1.1.1').ipv4
        ''
        """
        if not self.suffix and not self.subdomain:
            domain_parts = self.domain.split('.')
            if len(domain_parts) == 4:
                if all([i.isdigit() for i in domain_parts]):
                    if all([int(i) < 255 for i in domain_parts]):
                        return self.domain
        return ''

items.title: python 2.7 is often 'narrow', doesn't catch unicode error

labels.name: hold: a PR is pending
labels.description: a PR is pending that will address the issue (including if it is "X birds 1 stone")

items.body:
this example will work on python3.x but breaks on many default python2.7 installs (including many OSX and Ubuntu):

    import tldextract
    tldextract.extract('xn--vi8hiv.ws')

it will raise:

    ValueError: unichr() arg not in range(0x10000) (narrow Python build)

The problem is in that this block only checks for a `UnicodeError`:  https://github.com/john-kurkowski/tldextract/blob/2.0.2/tldextract/tldextract.py#L198-L204

however if Python wasn't compiled with support for 'wide' unicode, this will raise a `ValueError`

there are many strategies for supporting 'narrow' unicode, or this could just be caught and skipped.

items.title: docs: improve PyPi description and long_description
items.body:
The PyPi description currently reads:

> Accurately separate the TLD from the registered domain and subdomains of a URL, using the Public Suffix List.

This makes no mention of the package's ability to ignore private domains.  

Same thing with the long_description https://github.com/john-kurkowski/tldextract/blob/master/setup.py#L1-L22

I've passed over this library a few dozen times because I know what the Public Suffix list is, and needed to avoid treating the private domains as if they were public.  It wasn't until a friend told me "take a deeper look, it can differentiate between public and private".

items.title: tldextract does not parse private domains by default
items.body:
tldextract state that 

> tldextract accurately separates the gTLD or ccTLD (generic or country code top-level domain) from the registered domain and subdomains of a URL.

It is true but there is important information omitted from the claims.  
Apparently, tldextract DOES NOT parse all the domain inside the public suffix list, i.e.  private domain are IGNORED. 

```
import tldextract
domains = [
"subdomain.test.beep.pl",
"subdomain.test.ap-southeast-2.compute.amazonaws.com",
"subdomain.test.za.org"
]
for domain in domains:
    result = tldextract.extract(domain)
    print(result) 
```

results : 

```
ExtractResult(subdomain='subdomain.test', domain='beep', suffix='pl')
ExtractResult(subdomain='subdomain.test.ap-southeast-2.compute', domain='amazonaws', suffix='com')
ExtractResult(subdomain='subdomain.test', domain='za', suffix='org')
```

It seems tldextract read the public suffix list , reading everything above  // ===END ICANN DOMAINS=== and skip those underneath.

A note is required to warn the user on omission of the private domains parsing. 
Or tldextract should specify how to enable this features inside the documentation.  

```
import tldextract

]
extract = tldextract.TLDExtract(include_psl_private_domains=True)
for domain in domains:
    result = extract(domain)
    print(result) 
```

results : 

```

ExtractResult(subdomain='subdomain', domain='test', suffix='ap-southeast-2.compute.amazonaws.com')

items.title: Use JSON instead of pickle for tld data
items.body:
.tld_set_snapshot and .tld_set use pickle to store the TLD information. While this is perfectly fine in most cases it brings the following issues:
- Binary data stored in your git repository is a bad practice
- If this library gets packaged for ubuntu/debian, the maintainer will complain. I just started using tldextract in the [w3af project](https://github.com/andresriancho/w3af/commit/72c09c57ed588caf9bc1b5c9de686b85ebe7c072) which is part of ubuntu/debian. When the package maintainer packages the next version he'll most likely dislike the binary blob
- Pickles are "executables". A specially crafted pickle can trigger an arbitrary remote command execution when unpickled. While I did review the library for bugs and backdoors before including it in w3af, I did not read the whole pickle; which is bad for w3af user's security.

items.title: _asdict on ExtractResult empty on Python 3+
items.body: When using tldextract on Python 3.4 I noticed that the **dict** attribute of the namedtuple ExtractResult would always be empty, which caused its _asdict method to also return an empty dict.  This is because ExtractResult does not define a __slots__ member, which prevents the parent classes dict from being added.  I am not sure which version of Python changed this behavior.  I added a unit test (and also added Py34 to the tox.ini environments) for this issue and it passed for Python 2.7, but failed for Python 3.4.  Those are the only versions I had installed.  I fixed the issue in tldextract.py and all tests now pass, both in 2.7 and 3.4.  I created pull request #69 with the fix and additional test.

items.title: Incorrect suffix for punycode domains
items.body:
for example: 
"xn--h1alffa9f.xn--p1ai" results in
ExtractResult(subdomain='xn--h1alffa9f', domain='xn--p1ai', suffix='')

Workaround:

```
def tldextract_with_puny(url):
    if '.xn--' in url: #punycode domains
        o = urlparse.urlparse(url)
        url = o.netloc.decode('idna')
    ext = tldextract.extract(url)
    return ext
```

items.title: Add kwarg for `suffix_list_file`
items.body:
Here at Veracode we've made use of this wonderful library for quite some time now. It's great.

We'd like to be able to control the Public Suffix List input data more tightly. Namely, we don't just want to set an expiration, but to actually version-control the input data ourselves, and be able to specify a different version of the Public Suffix List file ourselves, at runtime.

This could be a keyword argument like `suffix_list_file`. The value would be the path to a file exactly like [the file that tldextract downloads](http://mxr.mozilla.org/mozilla-central/source/netwerk/dns/effective_tld_names.dat?raw=1). In other words, any plain-text file that is UTF-8 encoded. It should be newline-separated and conform to the syntax specified on the Mozilla Public Suffix List website, of course, but that's really up to the client to be correct about.

I am not 100% sure of what the relationship of this file would be to the `cache_file` and `fetch` arguments. It seems like the simplest way would be for this file to be a drop-in replacement for the downloaded Suffix List file. (i.e. read in this file if `cache_file` does not exist.) TBH, I'm not sure how to force TLDExtract to load in the data anew regardless of whether `cache_file` exists, at this point, so I don't know how this new feature would relate to that behavior.

I will probably fork and implement this.

items.title: TLDExtract is case-sensitive
items.body:
It seems that TLDExtract does not `lower()` its inputs before testing. So if you input `foo.CoM` it's not going to extract the suffix `com`. Case should be lowered because the case of the Public Suffix List is all lowered, and because DNS is case-insensitive ([RFC 4343](http://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc4343)).

```
>>> from veracode.utils.data.formatter import extract
>>> extract('example.COM')
ExtractResult(subdomain='example', domain='COM', tld='')
```

items.title: Conflation of the term "suffix" with "tld"
items.body:
Love tldextract, thank you. But I just wanted to suggest something... `tld` in the ExtractResults is actually representative of a _suffix_ not a TLD, as (a) this data's coming from the Public Suffix List, and (b) Assuming `extract` is an instance of `TLDExtract`, `extract('foo.co.uk').tld == "co.uk"`. In that case `"uk"` is actually the TLD, a country-code TLD to be precise. And `"co"` is just conventional... So yes it's good for them to be part of the same information, as we don't want to be told that the domain is `"co"`.

I think this misleading term could be easily resolved by changing the name of the attribute to `suffix`. Then just make a property that returns it (and doesn't get printed in `repr`), called `tld`, for backwards compatibility.

items.title: Feature request for caching
items.body:
Great library! Exactly what I was looking for.

One small request: I'd like to have a little more control over the caching of the public suffix list. We run jobs across a lot of machines, so each machine will get its own cached version of the list. I'd rather not have to manage the cached list on each machine. I think adding a cache expiration parameter would be a huge help with this.

Also, allowing the user to specify the URL for the public suffix list would be great, too. I'd like to host our own cache of the list, so we're not dependent on mozilla's uptime and bandwidth.

I think these two changes would add a lot of flexibility.

If you'd prefer, I can fork a branch and send a pull request with the changes.

items.title: Incorrect tld for appspot.com (support excluding private domains on lookup)
items.body: There are multiple uses of the Mozilla public suffix list which allow sites such as "appspot.com" to appear on the list as a tld instead of being split into domain="appspot" and tld="com". This is perfectly reasonable behavior for some use cases, but for others it would be helpful to have the "private" domains be excluded. Mozilla has split the list into "ICANN Domains" and "Private Domains", and it would be useful to optionally be able to exclude the private domains so that sites like "appspot.com" would have their tld reflected as "com".
